Writer-director Joe Carnahan was hired for the project because he's one of Hollywood go-to guys for brisk, adrenalized action, and he delivers - up to a point.

This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
David Letterman, Tiger Woods - we've certainly had our share of sex scandals in America last year.
But the exploits of those two celebrities pale in comparison to the allegations now leveled against a political leader from India, as NPR's Philip Reeves reports in his latest letter from New Delhi.
He really doesn't have the look of a lothario.
He doesn't strut or swagger.
He's not sleek or lean.
Age has left its mark on his round and baggy face.
Yet accounts of this man's sexual escapades have caused a mixture of outrage and amazement in India.
His name is Narayan Dutt Tiwari.
He's 86 years old.
Few outside India had heard of Tiwari until 10 days ago.
That's when a local TV channel aired a video that apparently shows him in bed with three young women.

The video astonished many Indians, partly because of Tiwari's age, but also for another reason: Tiwari happens to be governor of one of India's largest states, Andhra Pradesh, in the south - or rather, he was the governor.
Last week, he resigned.
America has a long history of outing public figures who stray from the straight and narrow, be they presidents or golf champions.
India does not.
It has more than 1 billion people, many of them still very poor, with much else to worry about.
They don't generally have high expectations of their politicians.
Legislators here are routinely accused of murder, kidnapping and bribe-taking.
Sex scandals involving politicians are rarely publicized, no matter how widely known.
That attitude may now be changing, though, thanks to Tiwari's alleged frolics.
The Tiwari video instantly made headline news.
It was an overnight hit on YouTube.
The media embarked on a debate about the meaning of the octogenarian's purported sex romps.
The pundits found much to talk about: Should India demand far higher standards from its public figures?
The post of state governor is widely seen as a form of political patronage, a job handed out as a reward for loyalty or favors.
Has the scandal damaged India's national government?
Tiwari's a senior figure in the ruling Congress Party.
The party is squirming with embarrassment.
Other questions focus on the media.
Should India's gung-ho TV news channels be in the grubby trade of peddling political sex scandals?
India has no shortage of hard-line religious extremists and is socially conservative.
But paradoxically, it also has a proud tradition of tolerance.
Will that change if the private sex lives of India's leaders are seen as fair game by the ratings-hungry media?
As for Tiwari, some reports suggest he's the victim of a sting after failing to keep a promise to hand out a mining lease.
He concedes he did entertain women at his government headquarters, but only official delegations.
He and his party insist the video is fabricated and that the only reason he's resigned is on health grounds.
He's actually won a few new fans.
We should be proud of this man, said one comment posted on the Internet.
It added, I hope I'll do the same when I'm 86.
Philip Reeves, NPR News, New Delhi.
Today in Dubai, residents will be marveling at the world's tallest building.

We've been hearing about financial troubles in Dubai but today, it celebrates the formal opening of the Burj Dubai skyscraper: a swimming pool on the 76th floor, a mosque on the 158th floor, and 169 floors altogether.
The chief engineer on this project says he experimented, adding one floor after another to see how high he could go.
The building is approximately 2,700 feet tall, which is more than twice the height of the Empire State building, although the exact height is secret, or may be unknown.

Frank, in Vacaville, California, pointed out that: sometimes the magic is so hidden, we don't even realize it's there.
I love special effects which are not apparent, he wrote.
In ""Gone with the Wind,"" the people don't realize that when Scarlett walks into the Twelve Oaks Mansion, the outside of the mansion didn't exist.
It was actually just outside the studio set.
The exterior was painted on glass, then the rest of the short was superimposed, making it appear that she'd walk into the mansion.
Don't you love the old masters?
Tim(ph) in California notes: that even the spectacular can age quickly.
Jurassic Park"" changed my life when I saw it in theaters.
As a 13-year-old boy, the dinosaurs look so real and life-like.
Unfortunately, seeing a clip today, it's almost too easy to spot the fake-looking T-Rex.
Our eyes are getting so good at seeing through the illusions that at some point in the past looks so realistic.
Even Gollum, from ""Lord of the Rings,"" fails to look as life-like today as he did only a few years ago.
Age can make the blue screens fall from our eyes.

I just wished he'd call it AromaRama.
Our show looking back at some of the lives we lost in 2009 brought in several hundred emails.
We love reading you remembrances.
Here are a few more.
John(ph) wrote: Roy DeCarava died this past September.
He was an influential photographer for the past 50-plus years, and the first black photographer to win a Guggenheim Fellowship.
I studied with him in the '70s at Hunter College in New York City.
He was not only a great photographer and teacher, but a warm and caring mentor who became a father figure to me.
He published photographs to a company, ""Sweet Flypaper of Life,"" by Langston Hughes.
There is too much to say about him here.
Suffice to say he lived a very successful and moving life, having touched many, many hearts along the way.
He will be surely missed.
Joanne(ph) from Colorado wrote: my husband's grandmother, Dolores Henderson(ph), died in April, just a few weeks before reaching the 100-year mark.
D was married to the test pilot, Jimmy Collins, a classic Hollywood movie called ""Test Pilots,"" starring Spencer Tracy, Clark Gable and Myrna Loy was made about their lives together.
D was a singer and model who perform in the ring ballroom.
She was a strong woman, a survivor.
She grew up outside Pond Creek, Oklahoma, where her family had homesteaded.
She lost the great love of her life, Jimmy Collins in a tragic ""Test Pilots"" in an accident.
The middle of the depression while raising two small children.
She was still teaching water aerobics in her 90s and driving in her 99th year.
She will be terribly missed by families and friend alike.
Howard Preston was a veteran of World War II where he was stationed in Germany and had the responsibility of running the bar and night club for his infantry.
He didn't drink.
So he was the only one they trusted with handling the liquor.
He was a crucial part of keeping the American troops relatively sane during the war.
He also transported various supplies between stations - a dangerous important and thankless task.
When out of the Army, he was a farmer and father of eight children for the rest of his life.
It's important to remember the little people like him.
If we've learned anything from our show, it's that there are no little people.
Again, thank you so much for sharing your memories with us.
You can always reach us at talk@npr.org.
Please let us know where you're writing from and give us some help on how to pronounce your name.
From NPR News, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Luke Burbank.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
A new grocery store is opening today in the North Dakota town that's named New England.
OK, this is not national news, but it is very big in New England, where they've been without a grocery store for nearly two years.
The Dakotas have been steadily losing population for three decades.
Small towns are just drying up, and the loss of something as seemingly unremarkably but as it turns out actually vital as a grocery store often leads to another ghost town littering the Great Plains.
